PolicyPage.Name: Pathway Acceleration
PolicyPage.Title: Pathway Acceleration
PolicyPage.BodyCopy:
The purpose of Acceleration is to allow an academically prepared student who plans to matriculate the opportunity to take a course in addition to the prescribed Pathway courses. This will allow the accelerating student to make progress toward a degree prior to matriculating. The Acceleration process is not intended for all Pathway students and is not to be advertised or otherwise publicized; it is expected that a student will initiate the process by making a request to take additional classes. The request is to be made to the student's Peer Advisor.


Suitability: A Peer Advisor, upon receiving a request from a student to accelerate, will carefully determine the student's suitability for Acceleration. In order to be suitable for acceleration a student must meet the following criteria:
 
Financial:
  • No outstanding financial balance or past-due holds
  • Must indicate an ability to pay for the additional course

Academic:
  • Must be earning either an "A" or an "A-" in their present Pathway course(s) o   A Lead Student or Advising Coordinator must verify the student's grades
  • A student who wishes to accelerate a second time must have received at least an "A-" in their last accelerated course
Other:
  • Must submit a calendar showing they have adequate time for the additional course
  • Consideration will be given to instances when students have struggled in past courses as indicated on transcripts. This is not a disqualifying factor but should be taken into consideration when deciding whether a student is appropriate for acceleration.
  • The Peer Advisor will be cognizant of other "red flags" that indicate a student may not be successful in Acceleration

Things to Consider:
  • A student is only permitted to accelerate one course per semester.
  • The grades a student receives while accelerating will be considered in their admission decision when the time comes for a student to matriculate. A student who receives a poor grade in a course under Acceleration may experience difficulty being admitted to the University to seek a degree. A student who fails a course under Acceleration may be prevented from matriculation based on their GPA.
  • A student who wishes to accelerate a second time must follow the same process; there is no automatic acceleration for students who previously accelerated.
  • The course a student takes while accelerating must be degree-relevant.  An accelerating student must take one of the following as their accelerated course:
                 o   A Foundations course
                 o   Foundations Capstone
                 o   An introduction course to an intended major        

Peer Advisors:
When a student expresses a desire to accelerate a Peer Advisor will do the following:
  • Ensure the suitability criteria are met
  • Assist the student in selecting an approved course
  • When the student is approved by a Peer Advisor for acceleration they must notify the Advising Coordinator who will issue the final approval and forward the information to the Online Support Center for authorization to take a course.
